<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 232, 293]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 278, 907, 293]]<|/det|>
9709/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 312, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Pure Mathematics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[730, 303, 907, 319]]<|/det|>
February/March 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Find the quotient when \(4x^{3} + 17x^{2} + 9x\) is divided by \(x^{2} + 5x + 6\), and show that the remainder is 18.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 528, 185, 546]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 528, 566, 548]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(4x^{3} + 17x^{2} + 9x - 18 = 0.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 529, 920, 548]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 87, 94, 106]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 416, 120]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\int_{a}^{3a} \frac{2}{2x - 5} \mathrm{~d}x = \ln \frac{7}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 127, 445, 145]]<|/det|>
Find the value of the positive constant \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 127, 920, 145]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 292, 92]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 92, 611, 114]]<|/det|>
\[3x^{2} - y^{2} - 4\ln (2y + 3) = 26.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 117, 636, 137]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the tangent to the curve at the point (3, \(-1\)).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 99, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Sketch, on the same diagram, the graphs of \(y = |x + 2k|\) and \(y = |2x - 3k|\), where \(k\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 118, 816, 138]]<|/det|>
Give, in terms of \(k\), the coordinates of the points where each graph meets the axes. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[918, 120, 923, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 575, 146, 593]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 575, 860, 594]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(k\), the coordinates of each of the two points where the graphs intersect. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[918, 575, 923, 593]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = x^{3}\mathrm{e}^{0.2x}\) where \(x\geqslant 0\). At the point \(P\) on the curve, the gradient of the curve is 15.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 128, 146, 148]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 119, 707, 152]]<|/det|>
Show that the \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) satisfies the equation \(x = \sqrt{\frac{75\mathrm{e}^{-0.2x}}{15 + x}}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 131, 920, 150]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 83, 675, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 293, 526, 314]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve with equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 322, 596, 341]]<|/det|>
\[y = 4\sin^{2}x + 8\sin x + 3,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 348, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
where \(x\) is measured in radians. The curve crosses the \(x\)-axis at the point \(A\) and the shaded region is bounded by the curve and the lines \(x = 0\) and \(y = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 395, 146, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 423, 413]]<|/det|>
Find the exact \(x\)-coordinate of \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 395, 920, 413]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 670, 146, 689]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 670, 485, 689]]<|/det|>
Find the exact gradient of the curve at \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 670, 920, 689]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
